page.title: 01HIGH MOORLAND ON SKYE
page.content: The block is a totally umpopulated area of acid peat moorland. More than half of the area has been planted or is being planted with conifers. These are mainly non-native species. Because of the small size of these conifers the heathers and deergrass are still the predominant flora. The non-afforested areas support a very small population of sheep and the occasional cow, wandering in from the block due west. The two small locks are used by the occasional angler. Due to the exposure and the poor soil the area is not rich in fauna although birds such as Golden Plover seem to find it to their liking. There are also small numbers of Greenshanks, short-eared owl, Dunlin and Red Throated Divers.
